Graphical abstract The graphical abstract summarizes the application of perovskites applied in different energy systems. Batteries, fuel cells, and supercapacitors are electrochemical devices already on the market and still need a boost in kinetics to match the high energy density demand of applications. Perovskites have attracted the scientific community's attention in the last decade due to their electrocatalytic activity, chemical and structural properties, tunability, low cost, and scalability. Efforts have been made to understand the active sites and the operational mechanisms in perovskite oxides to shape them as an electrocatalyst in advanced energy devices. Understanding the role of perovskites is the key to engineering more controlled and efficient electrocatalysts via chemical synthesis, and there is still much to do. This review highlights the use of perovskites in different energy storage and conversion systems. The A, B, and A&B doping-site effects are analyzed to understand the opportunities and challenges related to this class of materials. In addition, the synthesis methods and the properties related to the doping site are described and summarized. Keywords Perovskites Energy storage systems Electrocatalysts Battery Oxide fuel cells Capacitors 1 Introduction Society needs to develop a more sustainable energy matrix. This challenge goes hand in hand with new/better energy storage and conversion technologies to achieve a sustainable way of life. That would significantly reduce its reliance on fossil fuels, carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, and global warming. The metal-air batteries [1], supercapacitors [2], and solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) [3] are examples of technologies that pave the way to achieve the desired energy (10 kWh/kg) and power (100 kW/kg) density in applications. Despite the difference in the concept and application of the energy systems, the energy efficiency of all of them still needs to improve due to sluggish electrochemical reactions [4]. Considering metal-air batteries, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) occurs on the working electrode side during the discharging process [5]. On the other hand, an oxygen evolution reaction (OER) occurs during the charging process on the metallic Lithium/Sodium side. Water-splitting systems, the OER is the key reaction and also occurs on the anode side [6]. On fuel cells, the ORR occurs on the cathode side, the fuel oxidation occurs on the anode, and these are the reactions that determine SOFCs power density [7]. A widely investigated strategy to overcome the kinetics restriction faced by the oxygen reactions in electrochemical devices is to apply a suitable electrocatalyst. Electrocatalysts can increase the rate of electrochemical reactions due to their active sites, which achieve lower activation energies via the modulating binding energies of reactants, intermediates, and products [8]. Therefore, active, and stable electrocatalysts are essential to improve the energy efficiency and cost-effectiveness of energy devices [9]. Among them, mixed metal oxides such as perovskites, general formula ABO3, have attracted interest as catalysts due to their excellent catalytic, ionic, magnetic, and electronic properties. In ABO3 structures, A represents a rare-earth or an alkaline metal, while B usually is a transition metal, occupying the 12-fold and 6-fold coordination sites, respectively [10]. The main important fact about perovskite oxides is their structural tunability, enabling partial substitutions of A and B sites and various physical and chemical properties that can meet the need of a myriad of applications [11]. Working electrode designs allow better charge transport conditions and ion mobility in energy storage and conversion systems. Doping A and/or B perovskite sites is an effective way to change structural parameters that can enhance the electrocatalytic activities and, consequently, OER/ORR performance [4]. Thus, the study of perovskite oxide active sites has become a fundamental tool for achieving the best electrocatalytic results. Previous reviews have focused on halide perovskites [12–17], photovoltaics and photo/electrocatalysis applications [18–23], and a few are applied to the synthesis strategies [24,25], versatility [26] and energy conversion and storage [10,27–29]. However, up to now, there is not a unified correlation regarding the more advantageous chemical and physical characteristics of perovskite oxides to achieve high efficiency and improve cyclability in energy storage devices. This review aims to gather information about different strategies to synthesize and tune the perovskites used in several electrochemical energy systems and so investigate which perovskite active sites are deeply involved with ORR, OER, and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in the electrochemical reactions commonly found on energy devices. Therefore, we joined the information related to the structure and the influence of each active site, showing that tunning different active sites are possible to achieve similar catalytic performances using different perovskites. We proposed a reactional mechanism involving B-site doping of orthorhombic oxide perovskites considering the energy storage and conversion application. Future perspectives are also highlighted at the end of this review. 2 Perovskite oxides: characteristics and properties In 1839, the mineral CaTiO3 was discovered in the Ural Mountains, Russia, by Gustav Rose and received the name “perovskite” in tribute to the Russian mineralogist Lev Aleksevich von Perovski [30]. The Perovskite oxides family presents ceramics structures composed of one or more cations, with single or multiple oxidation stages, associated with non-metals anions (normally oxygen). Present general formula ABX3, where X is associated with an oxygen atom but could be occupied by halides, carbides, nitrides, sulfides, and other structures [31]. Besides the numerous perovskite types, in general, perovskite oxides are the most exciting compounds due to their crystal stability in different oxidation states [32–34], mixed ionic and electronic conductivity [35,36], easy synthesis [37], low cost [38–40], easiness for scaleup, extensive possibilities of applications, electronic [41,42], magnetic [43], optical [44–46], dielectric properties [47,48], and high catalytic activity [49–51]. The perovskites crystal matrix described by the ABO3 structure [52] presents a 3D framework with an octahedron conformation [53]. Their most advantageous use is related to their chemical versatility ∼ 90% [54] of the elements from the periodic table can occupy the sites and form compounds with a coordinate number between 4 and 12 [55]. The versatility is reflected in doping and modifying the stoichiometry, which inserts defects in the crystalline network, directly connected with various properties [56,57], and the versatility of applications [58–65] of these materials. A different type of low-cost perovskite material popularized in the solar energy field was the Halide perovskite [66–68]. They usually have a divalent anion and lead as B-site and the halogen normally is iodide, chloride, and bromide [69]. This perovskite class presents semiconducting properties that fit photovoltaics applications, driving the third-generation photovoltaics [70]. In this context, organic–inorganic lead halide perovskite stood out as a notable material for its visible light sensitization, repercussing in dye-sensitized solar cells [71]. In general, halide perovskites feature ionic and semiconducting nature which implies an effortless band-gap tuning [72,73] and optical absorption by just varying halide ions [70]. However, the efficiency of this material faces many challenges, such as its stability, presence of hysteresis, easy degradation in different ambient conditions, and the presence of lead [69]. It is essential to highlight that each family of perovskite stands out for its property, and this is what differentiates its application. In this direction, our study is focused on oxides perovskites due to their structural stability. 2.1 Structural and electronic properties Different types of crystalline structures present a unique conformation (bulk and surface structure) with specific planes, angles, and electron distribution, which contributes to the ORR, OER, HER, and hydrogen oxidation (HOR) reactions. This type of reaction relies on the A and B metal site dopants. In this way, each configuration stabilizes the material's physical and chemical properties [74,75]. However, many authors [29,76,77] compare different types of coordination to the same material composition. Zhou and Sunarso (2013) showed that the LaNiO3- x calcinated at temperatures varying from 400 to 600 °C present different types of crystal structures where the cubic coordination presents the best ORR/OER catalytic activity. The largest Fermi surface of cubic coordination compared to the rhombohedral structure allows the charge transfer in the reactions [78]. Despite that, it is a general consensus [79–81] that the perovskite oxide structure flexibility is the major advantage to enhancing the electrocatalytic activity until a limit due to the possibility of creating defects (vacancy/excess of oxygen). Some studies [82,83] demonstrated a reduction in the ionic conductivity related to the excess of defects which leads to an instability of the unit cell. An ideal perovskite structure is ordered in a cubic form (the A-site filling the bulk generated by the B-site on the cube edges sharing electrons, surrounded by 12 oxygen ions), as described in Fig. 1 (a) [84]. However, according to the type of element and method of synthesis, the crystalline phase can be organized in monoclinic [85], rhombohedral [86], orthorhombic [87], orthogonal phases [88], which changes the properties (Fig. 1b and c) [89]. Furthermore, A and B sites may suffer partial substitutions generating the oxygen vacancies, leading to a structural disorder called double perovskites, such as A1- x A’x BO3 or AB1- y B’y O3. These distortions increase the ionic conductivity due to their layers [90–92]. The magnetic, electronic, and catalytic properties of double perovskites are highly connected to the B-O rotations. The structure breaks motivated by the σ-bond are more effective than the π (t2g) bond, inducing the Fermi energy modification. Later reflected in the electron accommodation in the band of d-orbital and the electronic state, providing their desired properties [93]. In general, A-site is composed of a large non-catalytic cation and B of a small active ion. All parameters related to the structure configuration are correlated, the cation/anion ratio is able to determine the structure stability, and the spaces between the positive and negative ions can improve their mobility and distribution, determining the atomic packaging. For double perovskites, the tolerance limit is more difficult to specify due to the complex site coordination [94,95]. Considering a regular ABO3 structure, the coordination number of A and B-sites are 12 and 6, respectively. With the octahedral oxygen rotation, the bond length between the sites changes [96,97], resulting in a lower energy system that influences the valence and dipoles. Consequently, the structural changes interfere with the charge transport, oxi-reduction, and photocatalytic reactions [98]. On the other hand, the interaction of the external B-site orbitals (s and p) and 2p of anions create a valence and a high-energy band, as the inner d-orbitals of the B-site stay at the band gap energy [99], which is the necessary energy to the electrons arriving to the conduction band. Thus, the electronic transport properties are achieved due to d-orbital of B-site [98,99]. The 3d-orbital is broken into three parts due to the eg half occupation in the orbitals [100]. The structure symmetry is affected by the ionic radius, calcination temperature, coordinated number and oxygen vacancies [101]. All this could be seen by the crystalline distortion limit, with the filling of the unit cell by the other ions. The perovskite stability fluctuates between 0.75 to 1.0 [102,103]. It is described by the Goldschmidt tolerance factor (Eq. (1)) that determines the range limits. (1) f = r A + r O 2 ( r B + r O ) where r A, r B and r o are ions radius at sites A, B, and oxygen, respectively. As the degree of tolerance is closing to 0.7, the crystal distortion is higher [104–106]. In a stable structure, the B cation site has an octahedral orientation, and the interstice bulk has to be complete with A ions with optimum radius size [107]. If the A ion radius is too big, it can lead to distortion in B-O bonds that will have a hexagonal arrangement, however, if the size of the A radius is too small, the anionic arrangement will be different from the ideal form, improving the instability [94,95]. Perovskite structure is affected by electroneutrality. The sum of cations charges should be equal to the oxygen charges. When this parameter is not accomplished with partial/total ions substitution, different oxidation states lead to a defect in the matrix, which could be a cationic or anionic vacancy [108,109]. In the cationic bulk, the lack of A sites is the most common and the anionic vacancy represents the lack of oxygen in the structure. The oxygen excess is thermodynamically unfavorable; however, some authors reported this phenomenon for manganite perovskites like LaMnO3 or La1- x Mn x O3+ d [110–112], represented in Fig. 2 . The excess or lack of oxygen in the perovskite structure is affected by the non-stoichiometry [113]. The mobility of oxygen ions permeating the matrix and the nature of the ion referring to the B-site are crucial factors in the catalytic activity of perovskite oxides [114–116]. In the environmental context, this unusual behavior gained prominence in reforming the polluting gasses as automotive catalysts, likewise LaFePdO x , LaCo0.94Pt0.06O3, LaBO3 (B = Mn, Fe, Co) [107,117,118]. 2.2 Synthesis methods The perovskite has extreme flexibility due to site anisotropy, allowing a diversity of applications. The benefits depend on how perovskite oxides are synthesized. An overview of the most used perovskites is demonstrated in Table 1 . Many synthesis methods are described in the literature and could provide different crystalline structures. The flexibility of the perovskite crystal structure defines its extraordinary physical–chemical characteristics, mainly its catalytic activity [107,117]. Even though the perovskite properties are easy to tune, there is no consensus regarding the relationship between the synthesis method, the type and size of the ion, and the crystalline phases obtained, as shown in Table 1. Moreover, comparing the highlighted properties presented in the table, it is possible to verify that different material types could achieve very similar properties. Considering energy storage application, the synthesis choice will change according to the perovskite composition, as the dielectric and conductive properties of catalysts [142] are affected by the employed method. The dielectric properties are directly related to the perovskite type, considering double perovskite oxide. For example, orthorhombic Sr2CeSbO6 (SCS) depends on interactions between the cations (with different oxidation states) and oxygen content [157]. In contrast, the permittivity of LaCrO3 is enhanced by increasing the operating temperature. However, doped with Ir (LaCr0.9Ir0.1O3), this material decreases its dielectric constant [158]. Another high-energy material extensively used in different fields is SrTaO2N [159–162]. These perovskites present a relative dielectric permittivity from 1.6 to 1.7 × 104 F·m−1, and when applied at room temperature, it eliminates the dielectric losses [163,164]. Via ammonolysis of precursors from a citrate route, the cis-arrangement of Ni-ions in TaO4N2 octahedra induces tilting, leading to a local dipole with high dielectric permittivity [163]. Consequently, this material has a tetragonal arrangement, eliminating anion vacancy with the annealing reduces the dielectric losses. The Ba2− x Sr x CuO2CO3 layered perovskites were first presented as superconductor material. However, the actual interest changed with transitional metals like Fe, Mn, and Co substituting Cu [31,165]. Ba2LaSbO6 is an example of perovskites with chemical stability and a high dielectric constant that provides a superconductor for High-Temperature Superconducting (HTS) devices [166]. The copper-layered perovskites annealed at high temperatures were reported for the first time as superconducting materials by Bednorz and Muller in 1986 [167]. The superconductivity of the crystal could be affected by the synthesis methods as properties like structure defects, doping process, dielectric, and ferroelectric characteristics could change. The synthesis method employed in the perovskites could be chosen by the difficulty level. Solid state reaction (SSR) is the simplest synthesis route, which consists of grinding the precursor materials, and mixing them physically, followed by a thermal calcination process [168,169]. SSR is considered an easy and inexpensive synthesis, however, it requires high temperatures. Excellent properties could be obtained by applying SSR route, and the product could be obtained on a nanoscale. NaNbO3 (orthorhombic) produced by SSR for a blood sensor system showed excellent range detection when applied to sensors. The catalytic activity was boosted due to 3d orbital presence and the different types of niobium oxidation stages (Nb5+/Nb4+), enhancing charge carriers' delocalization [170,171]. The combustion method is an exciting option to avoid the calcination step due to the fast exothermic process. It involves chemical reactions, especially the redox process, which follows three steps: flame synthesis, heterogeneous combustion, and solution combustion (SCS). The last one is the most used in SOFCs, the primary oxidant is nitrates, and the fuel is an organic component (e.g., carbon and hydrogen). However, the fuel interferes with the material's crystalline phases, producing more than one [172]. Worth remembering in this regard that the combustion method is less environmentally friendly when compared to SSR as toxic gasses are not generated from precursors. The widely used method is the sol–gel due to its flexibility in mixing multiple types of metals, and it is based on the polyesterification of the reagents. The synthesis consists in solidifying a solution from a colloidal phase. There are five stages: 1) hydrolysis with colloidal and formation of polymeric chains due to anisotropic condensation - different properties along the molecular geometry irregularly retaining the condensation of the dissolved particles-, generating the hydrogel; 2) washing the by-products removing the interstitial solution; 3) followed by drying; 4) stabilization; and 5) densification [173,174]. The sol–gel enhances the porosity and controls the structure crystallinity during synthesis. LaMn1± x O3 is an ideal material to be used as electrodes for capacitors [175], and the structure is controlled by modifying the Mn content in the B-site. LaMn1± x O3 synthesized by the sol–gel method presented a cubic structure with oxygen vacancy defects, and mesoporous material, and when applied in a supercapacitor, a specific capacity of ∼200 mA h g−1 (current density of 1 A g−1) was achieved [176]. A modified sol–gel method developed by Pechini, known as polymeric complexing, aims to obtain a polymeric resin through the polyesterification process between metal and polyhydroxy alcohol [177,178]. Polymeric complexing stands out for the process simplicity, low contamination, and synthesis temperature. However, reagents are expensive and need to grind the product to reduce clusters [175,178]. It is characterized as a positive ions solution concentrated in a mixture of an organic agent (citric acid or EDTA) and ethylene glycol solution (polyhydroxy alcohol) [162,163]. The ions recombine with a chelating agent to generate a complex chemical compound attached by covalent bonds. After that, the product is submitted to a thermal treatment, in which the organic compound is decomposed [179]. The synthesis easiness and efficiency were confirmed by producing a single-phase orthorhombic Sm1− x Ca x FeO3 (0.1 ≤ x ≤ 0.5) at low temperatures with a ∼100 nm particle, which the Ca/Sm substitution could affect the Fe electronic structure or create an oxygen lattice vacancy [178]. Co-precipitation methods can be represented by an open system, where an aqueous stoichiometric solution is prepared with the precursors with solvent excess, alkaline or acid, to ensure the precursor dissolution. The mixture is constantly stirred, and precipitation occurs. Then, the obtained sample is washed to correct the hydrogen potential (pH), dried, and calcined. The co-precipitation method could be easily reproduced on a large scale but requires high calcination temperatures [180]. To summarize the steps involved in the synthesis methods we have done a schematic illustration shown in Fig. 3 . 2.3 Calcination process Materials used in the electrodes of energy storage devices need a high surface area to optimize the participation of components in chemical reactions [181]. The presence of impurities and different crystalline phases could block the pores, reducing the free oxygen content in the oxide matrix. In general, with high temperature, a pure phase of perovskites is obtained, however, this leads to a lower surface area [181–184]. The calcination temperature also impacts the ionic conductivity of all perovskite oxides and interferes with the densification of the atomic packaging and in the number of phases present in the crystal coordination (e.g., rhombohedral, tetragonal, cubic) [182]. The calcination temperature not only affects the crystal phases but also the particle sizes. Reducing the calcination temperature is possible to reduce the particle sizes and change the morphology. The balance between specific superficial areas, purity of phase structure, and calcination in low temperature is still a significant challenge due to a strong connection between these three factors. LaCoO3 synthesized by SSR method is a clear example that calcination temperature affects not only the particle's morphology, changing from spherical shape to a plated grain, but also the particle size could be doubled [185]. It is well known that particle sizes affect the catalytic behavior in electrochemical reaction [186]. Different factors are interconnected and contribute to excellent perovskite oxide performance. Many studies explain these parameters, their benefits, synthesis methods and applications, but still, more fields about them can be explored. Doping sites (A, B, or A/B simultaneously) and their influence on the perovskites' physic-chemical and structural properties are hot topics related to systems optimization, and they are further explored in the following sections. 3 Perovskite’s cation influence in different energy device 3.1 A-site doping The A-site doping process with lower valence ions is commonly reported, especially Sr and Ca [187–191]. In this way, the perovskite structure might assume a non-stoichiometric form, as previously mentioned in section 2, turning away from the ideal stoichiometric cubic perovskite ABO3. Fig. 4 shows Sr-doping on LaFeO3 (LSF), leading to oxygen vacancy formation. Considering an ideal perovskite structure, A-cation is larger than B-site. Later implies two significant impacts: 1) A-site electrostatic potential has a strong influence on the interactions and repulsions that occur in the crystalline network, which means that A-site can influence the energies of the valence bands and the conduction of the ions at B-site as suggested Madelung potential theory; 2) the size of the A-ion can determine the crystal structural distortion from the ideal cubic form [192]. Thus, A-ion size is essential in determining the structure's stability and crystallinity. The use of lanthanum cobaltite Sr-doped is widespread, considering that the oxygen vacancy increases when Sr-concentration is lower in the oxide network. Both stoichiometric and non-stoichiometric A-site Sr-doping perovskites result in the cobalt multi-oxidation state, increasing the oxygen vacancy and influence significantly the ionic conductivity. The multivalent cobalt, Co3+/Co4+ is predominant when Sr-concentration increases [190,193,194], as shown in Fig. 5 , which allows a successful behavior when applied in energy devices. Combining perovskite with carbon-based materials is a common strategy to improve battery systems' electronic conductivity and surface area [195]. It was proven that the pure crystalline phase of La0.6Sr0.4CoO3 (LSCO) mixed with Super P carbon act as a catalyst improving the OER in the Li-O2 battery. In order to obtain pure A-site cobaltite doped with Sr2+, the sol–gel is a consolidated method able to form a homogeneous, porous, and single crystalline phase (JCPDS 036–1393) [196]. Moreover, not only Li-O2 batteries but also the Li-S technology could be favored by using A-site doped perovskites. In order to immobilize the intermediate polysulfides (Li2S x , where 4 ≥ x ≥ 2) formed during the discharge system and improve the adsorption energy between Co atoms, the non-stoichiometric cubic phase of La0.6Sr0.4CoO3-δ are obtained using electrospinning route [197]. It is well known that Li2S x products can affect material activity and performance [198,199]. La0.6Sr0.4CoO3-δ-based perovskites used as active material in the cathode could reach 400 cycles showing an interesting catalytic activity for Li-S battery.Another alternative low valency element to modify the perovskites’ A-site is calcium (Ca2+) [200–203]. Ca-doped ferrite perovskite (BiFeO3) is an efficient hydrogen gas sensor; increasing Ca partial concentration, more oxygen vacancies were created, achieving excellent results in H2 detection. However, there is a limit for Ca-doping; above 15% the particle size is hardly affected, and also the structure; as a consequence,the sensor detection capacity was drastically reduced [204]. Perovskites’ optical and photocatalytic properties are also affected by A-cation. Theoretical models (DFT) proved that the catalytic activity for hydrogen production using La/Cr- doped ATiO3 perovskite is influenced by the size of low valence doping elements (A = Ca, Sr and Ba). To design better catalysts efficient in hydrogen evolution reaction, it is important to use an appropriate cation size to maximize the photocatalytic efficiency of the material. Although Ca2+ has the smallest cation radio, the structure had better activity than the Ba-doped structure, leading toSr > Ca > Ba in terms of increasing catalytic activity with dopants [205]. In theory, a small cation radius would favor the atomic approach and connection; however, this phenomenon was not observed. Surface area also does not influence the catalytic activity of this system since that Ba (∼22 m2 g−1) > Sr (∼7 m2 g−1) > Ca (∼3 m2 g−1), which differentiates itself from other studies [206]. The doping process makes possible the perovskite catalytic activity in visible light for hydrogen production, which was not viable using the pristine one. The great catalytic results are connected to the cation choice and the dependency on structural changes, especially bond length and angles. Lu et al. (2017) showed that Sr-doped perovskite presented the shortest bond length and proper bond angle between Ti-O, which facilitates orbital overlapping [ [ [Ti-3d and O-2p], resulting in a wide band dispersion andhigh charge mobility. Therefore, Sr-doped perovskite resulted in a highly crystalline cubic structure with the highest light absorption and catalytic activity, the best behavior for all features. Ca and Ba had longer bond lengths and angle bond deviation, which made the orbital interaction more complex, resulting in the tetragonal and orthorhombic crystalline structure. Manganite perovskites (AMnO3) are a promising candidates to be used as a catalyst for several systems like NO oxidation [207], supercapacitor [208], and lithium batteries [184] are well-known due to their magnetoresistance properties. These types of perovskites can change from antiferromagnetic insulators to ferromagnetic materials at lower temperatures when the A-site is doped with Sr2+, Ca2+or Ba2+ [209]. An exciting feature of LaMnO3 regards the prevalence of A-site defects and oxygen vacancies [208]. To enhance the superficial oxygen defects and from the lattice, hard-templating and impregnation methods are interesting tools, however, secondary phases could be formed [210]. In the case of SrMnO3 perovskites, the A-site doping process with Ca and Ba promotes the formation of a crystalline hexagonal phase. Ba-doped perovskites lead to more extensive lattice parameters when compared to pure SrMnO3 perovskites. When Ba is added to the structure, a lattice distortion happens, expanding the unit cell, followed by a high presence of oxygen vacancies and multiple Mn (Mn3+/Mn4+) oxidation states. 20% Ba-doped perovskites can increase the specific capacitance of an asymmetric capacitor, maintaining 87% of its capacitance after 5000 cycles. This is possible due to the oxygen vacancies surrounding Mn centers, which can accelerate the catalytic performance of the compound during charge/discharge in supercapacitors [211]. While vacancy allows catalytic activity improvement, it also could promote the breakdown of the structure and the formation of a secondary phase or segregation of oxides. Therefore, perovskite oxide can be considered a material of relative stability [212]. Aiming to obtain better chemical, catalytic or structural stability, many articles study the development of double perovskite [25,213–215]. The layered structure has several elements at A and B sites that can result in an ordered material with many surface defects [216]. A-site substitution affects catalytic activity due to increased structure stability, avoiding cation segregation and superficial amorphization in reactions involving water oxidation. A theoretical study used (PrBa0.85Ca0.15)0.5(MnFe)0.5O3−δ to prove that using Ca doped A-site can increase the oxygen mobility in bulk and, therefore, the catalyst chemical-electrochemical stability [217]. In the case of oxygen reaction, A-site cation deficiency could increase the electrocatalytic activity. In the case of lanthanum ferrite perovskites (LaFeO3), which have antiferromagnet properties, is it possible to synthesize oxygen deficient orthorhombic structure (La0.95FeO3-δ - JCPS – 88–0641) by doping A-site using sol–gel method. As a consequence, a high-performance bifunctional catalyst could be obtained, with oxygen surface vacancies increased and the Fe4+ species with eg orbital filled (t 2 g 3eg 1).Tailored A-site deficiency Sr x Co0.8Fe0.2O3−δ (x = 0.9, 0.95, 1), also synthesized by sol–gel, showed similar behavior, an increase in the oxygen vacancy and optimized eg occupancy of B-site leads to high active material for OER reaction [218]. Currently, a different way to modify A-site has been used to boost the perovskite activity through trivalent ion partial doping. Instead of doping with lower valence, specially Sr2+, the use of high valence A-site or the same at both sites (A/B). In this regard, cerium is becoming popular. However, this practice is not new and has been applied in different operations such as hydrogen peroxide oxidation [219], solid oxide fuel cells [220] and benzyl alcohol oxidation [221]. In summary, doping A-site with different valence cations can tune material properties, increase stability and catalytic activity [192,217]. Moreover, the technological progress involving electrocatalysis is directly related to developing complex oxides such as perovskite oxides. 3.2 B-site doping It is well-known that B-site substitution in ABO3 perovskites oxides will lead to ionic size and/or valence effects, which means significant changes in materials’ transport, magnetic [222,211] physical and catalytic properties of the perovskite [223–226]. Here, several studies are reunited to exemplify the effects and properties related to the B-site doping process (Fig. 6 ). In the case of B-site doping, the ionic radii of dopants play an essential role in the phase transition, which considerably influences the bifunctional catalytic performance improvement for ORR and OER. An obvious example is the NdBa0.75Ca0.25Co2- x M x O5+δ (NBCCM - M = Fe3+, Ni2+, Cu2+ and Mn2+) perovskites could change from orthorhombic to tetragonal phase by increasing the size of metals cations used in the doping process. However, these structural changes affect the electrocatalytic activity lowering the ORR kinetics when Cu is used as a dopant [224]. Au3+-doping enhances the electrochemical behavior of Sr2PdO3. Distortions in orthorhombic Au-doped strontium palladium perovskites could be caused by the substitution of Pd2+ for larger and more positive valence ions Au3+ [227], due to the oxygen vacancies in the lattice, which were created via charge compensation. The Au3+ dopant enhanced the electronic properties of Sr2PdO3, mediating the charge transfer rate and stabilizing the orthorhombic phase of Sr2PdO3. This type of perovskite B-site doped has been applied to biological areas and reveals that perovskite oxides could help produce non-enzymatic glucose sensors and be applied to other electrochemical energy conversion systems. The Co (B-site) substitution in SrCoO3-δ, SrCo1- x Sc x O3-δ (x = 0; 0.05; 0.1; 0.2), are promising Oxygen Transport Membranes (OTMs) and cathodes for SOFCs [228]. The doped SrCo0.8Sc0.2O3-δ, has an oxygen vacancy-disordered cubic crystal structure, while SrCo0.95Sc0.05O3-δ and SrCo0.9Sc0.1O3-δ changes to tetragonal structures with a hexagonal structure secondary phase. Undoped SrCoO3-δ (x = 0) presents a semiconducting behavior, on the other hand, for x > 0.05, a transition from semiconducting to a metallic conductive could occur, probably due to the crystal structure change from hexagonal phase to the tetragonal or cubic structure. A relation between Sc-dopingand oxygen defect formation exists [229]. Oxygen vacancy formation energies in the tetragonal phase were computed to be −0.69 and −0.70 eV (two different O sites), which means that it is less favorable to form oxygen vacancies for the tetragonal Sc B-site dopedin the SrCoO3-δ oxide. The ORR activity after doping with Sc could be improved. In terms of electrode usage the SrCo0.8Sc0.2O3-δ present lower electrode polarization (0.17 Ω cm2) compared to Sc-free SrCoO3-δ (0.22 Ω cm2) at 750 °C. The activation energy (E a) for ORR follows the presented order: SrCoO3-δ > SrCo0.8Sc0.2O3-δ > SrCo0.9Sc0.1O3-δ > SrCo0.95Sc0.05O3-δ. The mixed ionic electronic conductor (MIEC) perovskites as LnBaCo2O5+δ (Ln = Pr, Nd, Sm, or Gd) present a low-specific area resistance (ASR), high oxygen kinetics and good electrochemical performance [230]. Fe-doped cobalt-based layered perovskites PrBa0.8Ca0.2Co2- x Fe x O5+δ (PBCCFs) are effective as cathode material for solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) [231]. The tetragonal structureswith single-phase showed polarization resistance (R p) values of0.200 0.080, and 0.101 Ω cm2 for PBCCO, PBCCF05, and PBCCF10 at 600 °C. Fe substitution provides faster oxygen kinetics since the concentration of mobile oxygen species in the [Pr-O] plane was increased. However, it is important to realize that a high concentration of Fe could inhibit the oxygen kinetics due to the strong Fe-O bond, which interferes in the mobile oxygen channel. Fe substitution, PrBa0.8Ca0.2Co1.5Fe0.5O5+δ, could be a promising cathode material for intermediate-temperature solid oxide fuel cell as PBCCF05 achieved power density of 1.890 W cm−2 (PBCCF0′s 1822 W cm−2) at 600 °C. In the case of boosting hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activity B-site of tetragonal SrCo0.70Fe0.30- x Mo x O3+δ (x = 0, 0.05 and 0.1 and denoted as SCF, SCFM0.05 and SCFM0.10, respectively) could be used as electrocatalyst [232]. The overpotential of SCFM0.05 in catalyzing HER can be compared with perovskite Pr-doped BSCF [233], one of the best materials presented in the literature. This compound has also demonstrated the lower charge transfer resistance among them and the smallest Taffel slope of 94.21 mVdec-1 when compared to SCFM0.10 (140.13 mV dec-1) and SCF (189.63 Mv dec-1), indicating benefits to enhance electrocatalysis toward HER.Raman spectra showed a Jahn-Teller distortion within the BO6 octahedra for all cases, which increased with the introduction of Mo doping. An appropriate content of Mo is beneficial for the HER activity, since SCFM0.05 exhibited a superior HER activity with a more positive onset potential and a higher current density, compared with the un-doped SCF and SCFM0.10. X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) showed that tuning the perovskites with Mo species, would leave Mo to an oxidation state of 6+, consistent with the literature [234–236], and promote the coexistence of Co3+/Co4+ redox couple, more positively charged cations which are beneficial to HER [237]. Therefore, the B-site substitution in perovskite oxide can change many different properties of these compounds, mainly due to the oxidation state of cations in the system and the crystal structure phase. Those oxidation state changes contributeas active sites, boostingthe perovskites’ catalytic activity. B-site doping usually raises the number of defects in the structure, increasing the number of oxygen vacancies. Since the distorts enable mobility in the perovskite structure, electronic and catalytic properties are improved by B-site doping. 3.3 A & B-site doping Simultaneously, the non-stoichiometric doping of the A/B-sites could be considered an attractive way to combine electrochemical stability and the reduction of active energies from reactions as an electrocatalyst [27,29,238–252]. Mostly, the doping in the A-site is with alkaline earth metal, and B-site with transition metal ions can add defects to the crystal arrangement improving the ionic-electronic conductivity. One of the most usual substitutions is the quaternary perovskite oxide La1- x Sr x Co1- y M y O3 (M = Fe, Ni, Mn, etc.) due to an incredible catalytic activity produced by La x + replacement to Srx+ in A-site creating vacancies on the structure (Please see Fig. 7 schematic illustration) [253], while the total or partial oxidation of B-sites occurs which facilities the oxygen desorption [254]. Also, this type of perovskite has a variety of applications (fuel cells [255–261], water splitting [262,263], gas catalyst [264–266]) and has been extensively reported [267–276]. Teraoka et al. [277] and Chang et al. [278] described that the Sr2+ substitution for lanthanides increases the ionic and electronic conductivity, which defines a MIECs, as the A-site doping creates defects in the B-sites or the oxidation of B-ions which have different oxidation states (M3+/M4+). In addition, the metal element choice will be related to its affinity application [279]. The La1- x Sr x Co1- y Fe y O3 catalyst showed a great performance in many devices (e.g. fuel cells [280], batteries [281], gas reform [282]) and easily reverted the by-product through the presence of Fe2+/Fe3+ and many oxygen vacancies. The coexistence of Fe2+/Fe3+ plays an important role as an additional active site for oxygen reactions that provides their high oxygen exchange coefficient, which improvesfast kinetics reactions at the gas/cathode interface [278,281]. The battery reaches 20039 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1, encouraging the development of lithium-air technology [281]. The ion cobalt Co3+ contribution is not clear here; however, based on fewer studies in the literature, we can attribute to the cobalt ion the improvement of lattice oxygen mobility [278,279]. Generally, the proportion of Fe/Sr/Co contributes to different properties, arrangements, and system applications due to the interference in the crystallinity, varying from cubic, hexagonal, orthorhombic, etc. Tai et al. (1995) discussed that oxygen permeability is enhanced by increasing the Sr and Co contents of the perovskite. The reason is that the A-site lattice is a receptor that creates oxygen defects, while the Co ions on the B-site smooth the oxygen diffusion due to a smaller binding energy for O ions than Fe ions [283]. Thus, with the partial substitution of Sr and Co, the perovskite structure is rearranged to maintain stability while catalyzing the ORR/OER/HER reactions in all perovskite oxides. In this way, B-site valence increases to restore the oxide electroneutrality, allowing an increase in the mobility of oxygen on the lattice. Therefore, redox pair can be formed, creating more sites available for catalytic reaction, or A-site can enhance the oxygen mobility on the surface, and many oxygen vacations are formed. Zhang et al. brought a relevant discussion about the mixed element at B-site using Co and Fe ions for combustion of n-butane, methane and H2O2 in an alkaline solution. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) was used as the main resource to identify the oxygen vacancies and analyze the elements behavior of stability or multivalency. By TPD spectra, different oxygen species related to oxygen desorption on oxygen vacancy O- (named alfa) or the lattice oxygen O2 – (called beta) were identified. Considering La1- x Sr x Co1- y Fe y O3 perovskite, increasing Sr concentration, the oxygen desorption increases and any changes were seen in the alfa-oxygen related to Fe-concentration. The best catalytic activity was achieved using La0.8Sr0.2Co0.4Fe0.6O3 [284]. The A-site elements can influence alfa oxygen availability, which reflects not only on the number of oxygen vacancies but also the difficulty of regenerating oxygen vacancy. The composition of the B-site can enhance the desorption of lattice oxygen since the bond between metal cations and oxygen is altered [285]. Considering La1- x Sr x Co1- y Fe y O3 perovskites the strength of metal cation and oxygen bond is influenced by the concentration of Fe and Co [283]. Changes in the beta-oxygen concentration can show different oxidation states of B-site or increase the redox catalytic activity of the transition metal [283,285]. Also, the perovskite properties are modified by the partial substitution of Co and Fe ions [286]. Ba x Sr1- x Co y Fe1- y O3-d is an interesting perovskite, which is a variation of the SrCo1- x Fe x O3-d . The introduction of Ba ion improves the crystalline stability due to the modification of cubic to a brownmillerite phase (ABO2.5) which interferes in the oxygen stoichiometry reducing O2 permeation [287–290]. This happens because the Ba2+/Sr2+ ratio increments the site bonds distance, modifying the B cations valence [291–293], in other words, the mixed species on B-sites affects the orbital eg filling, increasing the OER activity, in this case [288]. Suntivich et al. also reaffirm that the media spin states on A-site cations are assigned by the t 2 geg configuration, their studies describe the importance of the bifunctional materials in which the ions have eg-filling surface close to 1 associated with oxygen covalency for better OER process [93,294,295]. The major benefits of this material are the many applications, stability, andavailability of electronegative heteroatoms. BSCFs are considered for industrial applications, SOFCs, Hydrogen evolution, or a bifunctional catalyst for metal-air batteries with surface treatment, doping, or synthesis effects [61,296,297]. Besides these regular oxides, other layered perovskites are explored. The advantages of doping A-sites with large cations (Sm, Pr, Eu, Gd) is to increase the catalytic reactions [298,299], specify when the original A-site ion radii are larger than the dopant ion,the substitution process creates a free volume in the perovskite structure, which will increase the oxygen diffusion [300]. Beyond that, for intermediated temperature SOFCs applications, the presence of cobalt causes system instability due to a high thermal expansion coefficient (TEC). Co-free like Pr0.5Sr0.5Fe1- x Cu x O3-d (PSFC), where the Fe substitution in B-site has good cathode performance, as the donor of cations replacing A-sites enhances the electronic conductivity. Coordinated crystal oxides are used to increase OER and/or ORR kinetics of Li-O2 batteries. Bifunctional catalyst LSM Ni-doped obtained by a simple sol–gel synthesis presented a structure with a high concentration of oxygen vacancies which enhances the electrons and Li-ion migration in the crystal structure, providing a strong O2 and Li2O2 bond as shown in Fig. 8 . This rechargeable battery reached 5364 mA h g−1 at 0.05 A g−1 of current density, with a longer lifespan of 79 cycles. The crystal structure had a smaller grain size (∼14 nm) than the undoped system with a high specific Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) area ∼ 14 m2/g that could present more catalytic active sites [195]. Detailed studies show the high oxygen permeability due to the bulk in A-site ions and lower polarization ofBa0.9Co0.7Fe0.2Nb0.1O3-d [301], also the presence of Ba reduces the Fe/Co oxidation keeping a steady cubic structure in other atmospheres conditions [302–304]. As previously reported [296], other authors discussed that doping with Nb ions results in major crystal stability, the highest acidity of Nb5+ ions leads to better resistance against acidic gases [305]. That permits its application of bifunctional electrodes or membranes [305,306]. An interesting aspect of perovskite oxides is how it adapts to the application necessities. One example is the SrFeO3−δ crystal (in tetragonal ordination)is a naturally mixed ionic-electronic conductor with excellent magnetic properties due to anti-ferromagnetic spin ordering. The nonstoichiometric flexibility is a benefit as the lack of oxygen generates the different oxidation states of the cations [307,308]. Solar thermochemical air separation, studied by Farr et al. (2020) describes the redox process with oxygen vacancies formed by thermal excitation, which reduces Fe4+/Fe3+ to keep the crystal stability, on the other hand, the oxidation (Fe3+/Fe4+) increases O2 partial pressure filling the oxygen vacancies to produce N2 [309]. Various types of ion dopants optimize the absorption effect. To A-site, Ca has a good kinetics oxidation historically [310,311]. In the B-site, Cu and Co restricted the structure distortion; they have an efficient performance due to the low enthalpy with a higher thermal expansion coefficient (TEC) that facilities the O2 permeation, but they are unstable with different phases formed when oxygen is inserted on the crystal octahedra [307,311–314]. 4 Is it possible to provide a standard mechanism to represent the perovkite’s activity? Different authors tried to propose a standard mechanism for perovskites. However, up to this moment, there is no clear answer to this question. We focus our review on getting all the information available in the literature to show that with different synthesis methods and A&B sites doping we are able to achieve quite similar properties, which makes each perovskite synthesized unique. Doping the A and/or B sites with metals leads to a non-stoichiometric form with structure stability (A-site doping) or to an excess/lack of oxygen and mixed valence of the dopants (B-site doping). With that in mind, the B-site substitution had pronounced effects on the phase structure, electronic conductivity, defect chemistry, oxygen reduction kinetics, electrode polarization resistance and oxygen permeability, most of them caused by the oxygen vacancies. Finding a general mechanism for perovskites is almost impossible as the metal cations and dopants involved in the structure, type of electrolyte and reactional conditions will completely change the reaction mechanism. The pH considerably affects the catalytic behavior of perovskites as metals could be leached and the electrochemical window, also, could affect the perovskites stability [315,316]. Moreover, the electrocatalytic activity of perovskites came from a combination of different parameters and for that reason we highlighted in this review the importance of synthesis parameters. In the previous sections, we showed that the chemical, physical and morphological properties of perovskites are affected by the synthesis method and calcination temperature. Theoretical studies combined with experimental tests already proved that conductivity and oxygen vacancy content plays an important role in the mechanisms involved in OER [317], and physicochemical properties of perovskites combined with carbonaceous species added to the electrode are crucial for ORR [318]. With all these constringes in mind, we propose a generic mechanism considering B-site doping as mechanisms involving A-site doping are not favored thermodynamically. In Fig. 9 , we propose a schematic illustration of possible mechanisms involving perovskites as electrocatalysts in electrochemical reactions considering the oxygen vacancy and metal sites as active sites where the reactions occur. On the top of Fig. 9, we show a hypothetical case of ORR and OER occurring in lithium-air batteries and using the aprotic medium. In the same way that the oxygen reduction reaction occurs, the molecular oxygen is reduced over the perovskite surface due to the oxygen lack on the B-site provided [319]. The redox couple of B cation overlaps the metal's orbitals and the oxygen, decreasing the Fermi energy [54]. LiO2 intermediary is formed and reacts with Li+, and if a strong interaction occurs, a lithiation process by a 2-electron mechanism occurs, forming lithium peroxide [320]. In an aqueous medium, the surface of perovskite is fully coordinated by hydroxyl radicals coordinated with the metal site [321]. During the oxygen adsorption step over the perovskite surface, the displacement of hydroxyl occurs, and a direct 4-electron reduction mechanism to produces hydroxyl radicals, as follows: O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - ↔ 4 O H - [310]. A similar procedure occurs in acid conditions; however, the oxygen reacts with H+ to produce water, O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e - ↔ 2 H 2 O [9,322]. Considering the OER mechanism alkaline medium, many researchers have discussed the adsorbate mechanism in which oxidative reaction occurs. First, the OH groups are adsorbed on the catalyst surface, then the deprotonation occurs forming an intermediate followed by the formation of *OOH species. After that, another deprotonation happens favoring the adsorption of *O2 species, the last step is oxygen desorption from the surface [323]. Among that there are also two mechanisms for Co-based perovskites involving lattice sites, the first is related to the mechanism that takes place in the metal-lattice, B-site and the second the reaction occurs in the oxygen site, indicating a surface mechanism [324]. The OER reaction is still a great challenge due to many steps involved in the electron transference mechanism; for this reason, we only proposed the reverse of the ORR process in Fig. 9. The HER shown in the same image represents the Volmer reaction, which always occurs in the same way that water is reduced over the perovskites and generates the OH–. The strong electrostatic interaction between B sites and oxygen avoids hydrogen adsorption [296]. 5 Insights and future perspectives The versatility of the perovskites application can be confirmed by the exponential growth of publishing articles from 1980-2022, Fig. 10 . The most reported perovskite structures are the rhombohedral, orthorhombic, and cubic phases, even with doping A, B or A & B sites. The lack of studies in the 20th century on perovskite oxides application in energy devices occurs because its use as an electrocatalyst started in 2003 and focuses mainly on the ORR, OER, and HER reactions. Fig. 10 shows a schematic illustration summarizing the past decades' leading publications involving exclusively perovskite oxides and perovskites in the electrocatalysis and energy fields. The development of electrocatalysts for oxygen reactions, using different synthesis strategies is fundamental to obtaining an appropriate design, which maintains the stability, the structure coordination, and the material neutrality. Although the perovskite role is not clear in the literature, yet, to obtain a deep comprehension of all involved perovskite active sites and mechanisms applied for energy storage devices, operando and in situ characterizations are fundamental [325–327]. This knowledge will guide a rational design of a perovskite oxide via chemical synthesis to enhance efficiency, cyclability and stability for a new generation of electrocatalysts applied to energy devices. X-ray synchrotron techniques are the most promising methodology to study advanced energy materials under dynamic conditions to tune and design new effective materials [328]. Structural and electronic characterization of the perovskite needs to be performed during the electrochemical reaction to investigate the role and the contribution of this versatile material in the electrochemical performance of the energy device. This knowledge will guide a rational design of a perovskite oxide via chemical synthesis to overcome and boost efficiency, cyclability and stability for a new generation of electrocatalyst for energy devices. For that, different techniques and methodology need to be combined to study advanced energy materials under dynamic conditions to tune and design new effective materials [328]. Advanced characterization techniques, like synchrotron-based, are the most promising for materials optimization and for the comprehension of perovskite mechanisms [329]. To understand the complex electronic structure, the active species and intermediaries over the surface of the perovskites X-ray characterizations are used [330]. 2D and 3D X-ray imaging provides information on morphological, crystalline phases, chemical, and redox details of tetrahedral and octahedral perovskites sites that allows an understanding of which parameters impact the device's performances. Using different energy ranges, it is possible to track the material's structural and chemical changes with a spatial and time-resolved resolution to fill all mentioned gaps. By performing operando X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis with the correct temporal and spatial resolution, it is possible to track the structural changes of perovskites and understand the unit cell parameter changes by Rietveld refinement [327]. In this context, it is possible to quantify the changes in the unit cell volume, correlate it with the reactional mechanism and provide valuable information about which site is the most active for each reaction. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) will provide information about the oxidation state changes and about the local environment of the peroxide oxide used. However, despite to be considered as promising technologies for future characterization [325,331], this type of technique, considering energy devices, is still a great challenge [332]. Raman Spectroscopy is an alternative to provide physical information on short-range order, phase transitions [333,334], changes in lattice dynamics [335], and ferroelectric properties [336,337]. By understanding these properties, we will be able to define which of them affects the electrocatalytic activity, the bifunctionality of this type of material and accelerate the reactions. Combining this technique with synchrotron X-ray will be possible to understand solid solution formation, perovskites disorder related to A and B sites [338,339], spin correlations, and excitations which allows a better synthesis choice. Another powerful technique that could be used to contribute to the understanding of perovskites’ mechanism is the online (operando) electrochemical mass spectroscopy (OEMS) which provides information regarding the gasses reduction and evolution [340]. Moreover, different X-ray techniques, synchrotron radiation and OEMS could be an easy way to distinguish all properties involved in the electrochemical process. There is no single technique that could explain the perovskites mechanisms, several approaches need to be used to fully understand electrochemical devices. Considering macroscopic and atomistic levels the theoretical models like density functional theory (DFT) are able to predict kinetic models, the protonation, the proton migration ability of perovskites, and provide a critical analysis of the material performance under conversion reactions conditions (ORR, OER and HER) [317,318]. However, is not possible to provide a standard mechanism for all perovskites and the computational cost to test all combinations is impractical. Knowing the oxidation states and structural properties under dynamic conditions obtained from advanced synchrotron characterization and combining it with DFT models it is possible to understand the effects of each perovskites site in the electrochemical reactions by analyzing how the electronic structure changes. Lattice parameters, the O 2p band center and hybridizations at the active sites, adsorption energy of the involved species, and the reactive intermediaries also could be determined by DFT and will be affected by the perovskites sites composition and by the dopants. 6 Conclusions We have reviewed the perovskite with different electronic configurations and chemical compositions, discussing chemical, electrical and structural properties. The oxygen vacancy combined with metal sites turns the perovskites oxides mechanism complex and the type of electrolyte plays an important role in the reactional process. Until now, there is no consensus in the literature regarding the perovskites mechanism in ORR, OER, and HER reactions. Developing electrocatalysts for oxygen reactions using different synthesis strategies is fundamental to obtaining an appropriate design that maintains stability, structure coordination, and material neutrality. Structural and electronic advanced characterization of the perovskite needs to be performed during the electrochemical reaction to investigate this versatile material's role and contribution to the energy device's electrochemical performance. In concern of future perspectives, the combination of different advanced image characterization is the most promising alternatives to deeply investigate the complex structure of perovskites. However, a lot of effort needs to be done on cell development and design to obtain reliable results. DFT calculations combined with experimental results are an alternative to provide realistic mechanisms for each material and fill the lack in literature. coredata.dc:description: Batteries, fuel cells, and supercapacitors are electrochemical devices already on the market and still need a boost in kinetics to match the high energy density demand of applications. Perovskites have attracted the scientific community's attention in the last decade due to their electrocatalytic activity, chemical and structural properties, tunability, low cost, and scalability. Efforts have been made to understand the active sites and the operational mechanisms in perovskite oxides to shape them as an electrocatalyst in advanced energy devices. Understanding the role of perovskites is the key to engineering more controlled and efficient electrocatalysts via chemical synthesis, and there is still much to do. This review highlights the use of perovskites in different energy storage and conversion systems. The A, B, and A&B doping-site effects are analyzed to understand the opportunities and challenges related to this class of materials. In addition, the synthesis methods and the properties related to the doping site are described and summarized.
